LONDON, Printed for Humphrey Moseley, and are to be sold at his Shop at the Princes Armes in St. Pauls Church-yard. 1649.

list.item: SIr William, A Sutor to the Lady Beaufield.
Master Newman, A Sutor to Mistris Lucy.
Formall, Gentleman-usher to the Lady Beaufield.

div.head: Act I. Scaene I.
div.stage: Enter Sir William (at one doore:) Mr Manly (at the other.)

sp.speaker: Sr. Wil.
sp.p: I Ack Manly, well met.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Noble Sir William the humblest of your servants.

sp.speaker: Sr. Wil.
sp.p: Come, thou shalt along with me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Sr. Wil.
sp.p: To see my Mistris.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: May you thrive in your courtship to her: at this time I am engag'd to other business.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Can any thing concerne a Gentleman equall with a handsome Lady?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, the receiving of money is more considerable with me at this time, than all the women in the world. But who is your Mistris Knight?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p:
I dare tell thee, Madam Beaufield, the
Lady of spirit, and entertainment, the only Magnetick widdow i'th Town.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: They talk her a wit, and a most superstitious observer of persons, and their garbes; I never had the happiness to kiss her hand, or be known to her, but I converse with some who are very high and loud in her character; another time Enter Jeere Major, and Minor. Ile wait upon you. Who are these?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: In what grott hast thou spent thy time, that thou art ignorant of these people? These two are held the wits; That is the remarkable Jeerer of the Town, and 'has purchas'd to himself the title of a Jeere Major.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why, Is there a Regiment of Jeerers?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: You shall pardon me, there are sets of them, as there are of Fidlers; there is first a set of Court Jeerers, spruce half-witted men, confident, and fierce in their opinions; these are men that make themselves musick, and their cloths make roome for their wit; and go before in all companies: Then there is the town Jeerers, like Hoboyes or Waites of the City, that think they are wise when they are loud, and make a noise when they come to Plaies, to distract the next mans understanding. There are Jeerers at time of the yeer that go down into the Countrey, and infect Wakes, and Faires, and the Sizes, with their impudence, with which they save charges, and are never without the name of a great Lord, to whom they are cosin Germane.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But what has he deserved to be called a Jeere Major, and to beare such a title? I have seen the Rooke.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: An excellent ill nature has preferd him to opinion: the other has merited but the name of a Jeere minor; yet they can see me pleasant in their reproaches, and laugh in their own defence, which many times keeps off the cudgell.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay, Jeering is a blessing that every man may have if he give his mind to it: but wit (if I remember what I was taught) happens not to one amongst five hundred on 'em. But I forget my affaire.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Shall's meet and be merry this Evening.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: There's no musick in me without my singing birds about me, then I am a Lord, and when I put on my habit of Leister, I am his own excellence.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Dost thou preserve that him or still?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I may chance by the false light of the Evening march to thy Lodging.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Dost know where tis? I am remov'd. (whisper.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So, no discoveries what Prince I am.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: A match: that shape will beget us some mirch.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Your most humble servant. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: My Mistris is somewhat melancholy, if he come in that phantasticall habit, we shall have rare sport beyond his expectation, to have the Ladies laugh at him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: This is very fine wit yfaith, and soone learnd I thinke; a little more on't sweet Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Jeer.
sp.p:
Suppose you were foxd last night; thus I come to you, and accost; Save you Sir; you must
know I must laugh all the while; how fare you Sir? Do not some fumigations remaine, some vapours not dissipated, a kind of Vertigo, a weakning of the Nerves, or so? Ha, ha, ha, what thinks your Worship of milke now, thin broth, or a Julip of pitifull Six for a penance to settle you, or a haire of the same whelp? Ha, ha, ha, there's wit for you.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: There's no harme in the world in it, nor no exceptions if you laugh in the right place.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Now imagine you met an honourable Gentleman that had got a hurt in the groine; thus I invade you; but the laugh must hold me too.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: By any meanes, I cannot choose but laugh my self.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: There is no safe jeering without it.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Sir, you have been at push of pike and received a hurt, upon some unslaught in some female service, Ha, ha, ha; your breath is Aromatick since you kiss'd your Mistris, and your water out-smells the violet, ha, ha, ha; by the powerfull— yclipped Turpentine, tis true; what pitty tis you went without a charme, or had no acquaintance with a Laplander, to make you Venus-shot-free? Ha, ha, ha; and how many french tennisballs have you in your flanke now? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You sate up at play all night, and lost your money; another now.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Not I a penny, I sent a buffe Gentleman that lookt big upon me, after an ill hand, twenty peeces upon halfe a dozen oaths.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p:
A good pawne, keep his oaths, if he do not pay your money, take the forfeit, and if he be
a Gamester he'll be undone for want of swearing.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Suppose it lost?

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Me thinks Cavallier you looke pale since you came from the charnelhouse, did the bones affright you? you are a most religious Gentleman when you are at dice, and do so pray for 3 fives 3 foures at in and in: with what devotion you look on the seven of Spades and eight of Diamonds at cribbish? ha, ha; how zealously you invoke the Saints to fit you with cards at picket, or lebet.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I invoke the Saints?

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: I speake to the catholicke gamester, that understands all games.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: By the way though, doe you think there are any gamesters in heaven?

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: It is to be feared, they may lose so much upon earth, they will hardly purchase a place there, or if any get thither, (which must be excellent throwing) he would be more call'd upon, and perhaps puld downe agen, upon every dispute at play to be Groome porter.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: How like you these?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: You shall both with me to my Mistris, and help to Jeere my rivalls.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Your Mistris?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I Mistris Lucy, Lady Beaufeilds daughter, my Landlady Mistris Voluble has commended me to her, and I hope to carry her, if one Gentl. that she loves better do not get her away?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: Wee'l jeere him to death.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
That were an excellent way, I thinke there is no statute against that, I care not what becomes on him, he put bitter jests upon me tother
day before the Ladies, and I making use of your wit Gentlemen, he told me to my face, that I talk'd nothing but clinches; as I am a Gentleman he did.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Oh barbarous!

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: You shall wound him with his owne weapon, and by a direction we can give you, you shall so jeere him, that he shall offer boote to change understandings with you.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Wee'l make him so ridiculous, he shal laugh at himselfe.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: That will be rare; I have sent for my Mother to towne to be acquainted with Ladies, and learn dressing; my Landlady, hath promised to commend a Gentlewoman to waite upon her, and teach her the art of painting, and all the postures of a great woman; I do meane she shall marry some Knight or other, and be Ladified.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: It wil be necessary.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Though I say it, the woman is flexible, and has been in her daies— My Father might have been a Knight, and he had not been an Asse, and lov'd his mony; but we lose time, let's to my Mistres Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: We attend sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: The same day, a Dolphin taken in a net at Woolidge, and ten live Pilchards in a Salmons belly— strange things! the 13. of July, the Caramountaine kittend in the Tower: an Eeleship spring a leak shooting the Bridge,— heere are prodigious things. Enter Newman.
Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: New
sp.p: Mr. Usher, how does your Lady?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: She is in health.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: And Mistris Lucy?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Both in the Garden. Sir you have good intelligence, what newes abroad? a touch to your servant.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Alas you are acquainted with the state mysteries.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Troth Sir, I know little, or if I did, I would be loath to speake it, but to a friend, the times are dangerous.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Y'are right Mr. Formall, but be not nice, I know you are furnish'd with newes, as well as some that give pensions, though 'twere to a Captaine in these warlike-times, to have it made for 'em; you being a quotidian ambler upon impertinent visits, must needs gleane the secrets of the court and state.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Sir I dare trust you with any thing, but pray do not speak on't; there is a great man in the world—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Think you so?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: That—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What has he done?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You shall excuse me; but—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What his name?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You shall excuse me for that too; a word to the wise; you can guesse what I meane, and let that passe; and now we talke of state affaires, there is a packet come out of the North, and a box— in your eare sir.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What is said to be in that packet?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Ther's the businesse, but that no body knowes.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Tak't upon my word; you are a friend, I heare further at Mr. Secretaries, but you must say nothing of it, you undoe me if you doe, the King goes to Hampton Court next weeke, but how long he stayes is uncertaine. Sir, you see I put my selfe into your hands.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But is this done like a wiseman to reveale these mysteries, to trust these secrets to one you have not known above 7 Yeare, if I should inform what will become of you, and your estate? oh you must be cautious, though for my part—

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Oh Sir! I know to whom I speak, and will tell you more, for I dare trust you with my soule; they say the Northerne progresse holds this yeare, and that the Elke is dead in the new great parke

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I hope not.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Tis as I tell you, by the fall of a tree, doe not you remember a tempest foure nights agoe? then 'twas, blustring times Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: That makes Van Trumpe so troubled with the winde colicke, but now the Hollanders, as they report, have many Engineers and Mathematitians set a work, how to keep and vent it at their pleasure, and so to serve in Navigation for their ships, that there may be ventus liber, as well as ventus clausus, answerable to the two Seas.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Ha, ha! that's newes indeed, alas mine is but domestick, but what do you heare of London Bridge? it is whisper'd by some it will, and some againe point blank say it will not be repaired; but make not me the Authour.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
And I do heare the Camells decay at
Tiballs: but pray no more of it from me.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You shall not doubt me Sir, you do not heare of the Dolphin—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Of France?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Taken as Woolidge in a net.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Of Italian cutworke.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: The newes is not common of the Pilchards, the Catamountaine, nor the Eeleship?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Not a word.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You shall heare more; I am your servant. Here is Mistris Lucy Sir, and Mistris Voluble.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I confesse he has no overcharge of wit, that will be your happinesse, he has a good estate, and you may live with more delight than a court Lady, he is a handsome man too, I am bound to give you my advise, for your mothers sake, whose servant I am by many obligations, she has been my customer for face-water, and pomatum these many yeares.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: But if you be so skilfull, as you are profest, and read in the secrets of nature, you can tell by your art where I shall fixe my affection, doe not you know Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I never see the Gentleman, but I am not ignorant that he matches in the Vanne, and leades the file of your amorous servants, but—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: If you love your selfe.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He is a well-bred Gentleman, and one deserves my good opinion, hee's here.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They observe me— Exit Form:
I kisse your hand faire Mistris Lucy: what's she that lookes so like one of the Sibills?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Is this the Gentleman you declare so civill, and well-bred, Lady? If I have any skill take heed on him, he has an unlucky countenance.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: This Gypsey will but cozen you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: She is excellent cunning, and has foretold strange things, beleeve it.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: If my Mistris have an opinion of her Art, she may do me a displeasure; I have heard much talk of this woman, some say she is a Witch too, and weares the Devill in her thumbe Ring, I would not anger one of her Familiars. Take no offence Mistris at the rudenesse of my Language, this Lady shall give a very faire pawne, the word of a Gentlewoman, that I shall be of good behaviour, if you please not to interpret me too hastily.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: There is some text in your forehead Sir that wants a comment, but Ile not so much study your satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Nay, thou shalt not be displeased with him.

div.stage: Enter Lady Beaufield, and Sir William.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Alas, I am not angry; here's my Lady and Sir William.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You are Master of an excellent language Sir.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: You honour me too much, it is because you are the excellent Subject Madam, and being the perfection of your Sexe, an argument to create Eloquence in every tongue.

sp.speaker: Beau
sp.p: Then I must think you flatter; these praises are misplac'd. I shall suspect you love me not, or are not wise.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Why Madam?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You take such paines, and make a pilgrimage to that's within your reach; I must confess I like Discourse, but think not all my soule plac'd in my eare; although I love a Lute well, it follows not I should dote upon a Cimball.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: A Cimball?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And dance as I were stong with a Tarantula, when you are at it, rosting of a Galliard? You overdo this instrument, give me your courtship in a phrase is fit to own and understand.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Your pardon Madam; I affect not bold and over-rack'd Hyperboles, although I might insist upon the wealth and fulness of your merits, to which, all praise, that can flow from me, is Justice, such command you have upon your humble Servant, I rather wish my tongue a forfeit to perpetuall silence, then with one harsh sound offend your eare; you'l give me leave I hope to say I love you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: This is English Sir, and some do call it sence; 'tis faire, and fit, when any Lady's private with her Servant; 'tis what I learn'd a child, I have not yet outgrown the knowledge.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Did you love so young?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p:
I understand the meaning of your language, 'tis not perplext, and you may love me too, and tell me so, and I may understand you; what need compartments here, freeses, and words of Architecture, that will make things hard to the understanding? As you could not build a sence in love without 'em? Yet I bar not the freedom of Discourse, and use of Metaphors: And you may praise us too in Verse, or Prose, to shew the exaltation of your wit in company, but 'tis the worst
discourse when we are private.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: If I had confidence she would direct me— action I beleeve when opportunity Invites—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: To what good Knight? be not mistaken, I commend courtship in words, that are made round like pills fit to be swallowed, and not ragged bullets.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: 'Tis a strange Lady, I know not how to take her.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: My Lady? Madam—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Art thou come?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Is it your Ladiships pleasure I shall read to day?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: By any meanes, the Ladies will not faile, we should forget our Academy: Sir William we must entreat your patience, and Master Newman. Vol. whispers to Sr Wil.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Madam, the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Say I wait upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Ile take my opportunity.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You will engage him to credulity, and prepare some mirth.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Mounsier Galliard the Dancer attends Madam.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: He must give way to another exercise; Sir William you shall do us a favour if you please to entertaine a little time with him in the next Chamber, our Lecture will not be long, and sweet Mr Newman the French-man will delight you with his discourses, he has a tongue as confident as his feet, if you can but humour him.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: You shall command us Madam.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: That Done wee'l joine societies and mirth. Come Mrs Voluble.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I hope you will excuse my imperfections. Exeunt.

div.head: Act II. Scaene I.
div.stage: Table and six Chaires set out. Enter Lady Beaufield, Lucy, and other Ladies, Mistris Voluble.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
IT is an infinite favour, (most excellent Ladies) and must needs speak the sweetness of your nature and dispositions, that y'are pleas'd to hear me, so weak and unworthy of the Chaire, rather deserving to be in the number of Disciples, than a professor in any of the female sciences; but as your vertues are more exemplary, in this honour to me, the humblest of your Servants, it will become me, in the gratitude to so noble a bounty, not to waste time, but succinctly to deliver, what I could not finish without trespasse on your patience; at my last reading I did conclude with old Ladies, that will cozen Nature, and Time, and abuse the men they love best; to these I only add, it is not Mercury to change their skins like Snakes, but they must fill up wrinckles as well as hide gray haires: your red leather is for Countrey Wenches, your white wash, or Spanish Fucus is the best, but a tire woman,
or coverer of time or nakedness must be kept in pension: for it is now fashionable to buy one of her apprentice Girles out of her time, as Lords and Gentlemen do Barbers boyes. Amongst other ornaments, Ribbands challenge no meane place, the variety, and blason of these, I have elsewhere examined. For your finest Laces, the Angel in Cheape, but they must be dearer then others, because they come in Coaches, for pride or stateliness in any thing adds charges. Touching Gloves, might I advise, I would have a few selected Ladies, to procure some ingenious Gentleman at a reasonable pension to lye leiger for them at Rome for Frangepane Gloves, and such other correspondent things as may be of moment and great consequence to your Ladyships: But then I must advertise, and most seriously, that he may be a man of parts, and somewhat smelling toward the Roman Wash, that he may give you intelligence of that State, and humours of the Cardinals, or those that pretend to it, be they little or great, for this concernes the state Ladies here: For your swarthie Mountebanke Italian, he utters sophisticated Holborne Gloves for Frangepane, Essex Cheese for Parmesan, rotten post for sweet powder, pickled white Leather for Mushromes, and cozens more with his broken English, then the wits can get honestly with their best language.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady
sp.p: The Merchant of Italian Saulsages, A meet Quack.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
But then I would advise your Ladiships to have another Gentleman sent into Spaine for perfumes, pocket Fannes, orange flower water, Orange flower butter beauty, Aqua de Chedrey,
and many provocatives, as Contra yerua, and Joco lata.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady
sp.p: It is a very learned Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: For Holland, 'tis too deare in Spaine, therefore for a conscionable cozenage over and above, here are honest Dutchmen will serve you most faithfully. For Jewels, you may buy them at what rates you please, they add lustre to a Lady, and you may sell them at a fift or sift part, which is very well for a great Madam, if you would put them off at the best rate, you must get some Doctor of Phisick, or broking Apocriphall Captain, to shew them (as if there were fornication in it) behind the doore, hanging or curtaine, which makes his fingers like Jewellers cardes to set rings on, for there are bawdes for rings and Jewels, as well as for other commodities.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: What do you think of this caution Madam?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: For your Linnen, it must be fine, and fresh every day, therein consists humane delight. For linnen breeches, though some think them cleanly, in my opinion they imitate a Dutch Stove too much. For Aprons, plaine Holland is most becomming, starch'd Lawne was in Queen Elizabeths time, and will not endure rumpling, every thing must be squar'd by use and elegance; but for your white Shoes, rich Roses, light-coloured silk Stockings, and such variety below staires, they are great Inducers, as a learned man told me, (I will not say a Divine) for Love, most excellent Ladies, doth sometimes ascend, as well as descend.

But still remember Ladies, that your Fanne be so little, as not to lose the least smirke, or grace
of your countenance for it, for then being so small, when you put it to your face, some Courtiers may take it for a black patch. Then for your oaths, I protest is out of fashion, I professe for a Justice of Peaces Wise, I vow too masculine, yfaith for a Chambermaid, Introth for a Landerer, As you hope to live, too like a Prayer; Never stir, would disadvantage a Lady many waies, besides visits; For the active wenches of the time, May they be damn'd eternally, and lose all their designs if it be not so; Upon my honour sounds well, which in a great Lady can never be forfeited if she be in love, for great women have their privilege of Nobility, and can never be forsworn like the Common people.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Is Perjury in women no breach of Laws?

sp.speaker: 4 Lady.
sp.p: You have the Doctors opinion.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: One touch, if you grow old, which I omitted formerly, When time, which is the moath of beauty, creeps upon you, you must be sure to have so many leaves and curtaines before your windows, that you may shew your selves at more various lights than the most cozening Mercer his faded and deceitfull Wares, for the youth of your white Satin will be then but pearle colour at the best, it may be but ash-colour, and therefore refuse no advantage to give it gloss, according to the conclusion of a moderne Poet, which at this present shall be mine.

quote.l: Wise Ladies must refuse no Art
For age will snow upon their heart:

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p:
You have done us a great honour, and Ladies you shall not deny me this favour to taste of a small banquet that waites upon you in the
next roome, shall I shew the way. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir William, Mr. Newman, Monsieur Galliard.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me be content to have de litell patience, and be my trot, me tell you, vat me have seene a to day, de fine sport in de, me come into de great man to day, me make de reverence Alamode, come ill faut, and he make me de estrange a Sir reverence de tird time, dat ever you saw.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: That was not civill.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Oh Monsieur, every man has not the activity of your feet.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: By my fat, 'tis very estrange a ding, dat dey will suffer a des men to be neere a de King, a de Queene, de Prince, or de Princesse, dey vil marra de understanding very mush.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Why Mounsieur that lyes at the other end.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you shall excuse a me, for de Courtier Alamode, dere de vit lie in de foot, begar mi is nobodie can be viseman, dat does no make a de most excellent reverence, dat is most certaine, dat is the best ting in de hole varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I am cleare of his opinion.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But do you think Caesar Sir, or most of the Emperors or worthies of the world, studied the liberall science of the foot, or puissant toe?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: No, but begar dat make dem dye all unfortunate, for if dey had tinke of noting but de reverence, dey might ha live a great a while.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Excellent well argued, and very cleare in my understanding.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
I confesse the wisedome of it Sir, but
for the wit do you thinke that lyes there?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Dat be de best vit can be possible, for your vit, vat is your vit? your vit is to breake a de jeast, vel, looke you now a me, me vil breake a de jeast, dat is like dat a me lor, dat is like dat of de Knight, dat is like dat of de Ientilman, ha, ha, ha! dere is now one, two, tre very good jeasts, by my trot dey are so very good jeast, dat make a me sicke wide laugh, and begar me vil make a de page, de lacquey, & all de foole in de court, breake a des very good jeast, very quickly, dat is a noting.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: To any purpose?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What doe you thinke of the grave Aldermen? they are wise, and yet they doe not trouble themselves much about legs.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Be my trot, me speake a to de King, and to de Queene, to give me a patten, dat none shall teach a de Aldermen to make a de reverence but my selfe, and me vil undertake dat vid in one 12 a mont, but den dey must doe nothing else, dey shall make a de reverence, vid de Aldermen in de paris, and dance a Coran, a Cereban, a Mountague, and dat vil be very brave.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What faculties some men have?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But what shall businesse do in the meane time Mounsieur?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Is not dis very great a businesse? may begar, me vil undertake to de King and to de Queen to make a my Lor Mayre de Sheriff and de Aldermen very fine a mask.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: And to write it Mounsieur?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Aw, de write? dat is noting alamode, your speesh two, tre, yard long, pshaw? give a me de quick a spirit, de fancie, de brave scene,
de varietie of de Antimasque, de nimble a foot, no matre de sence, begar it vole be de brave in de christian varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: There is no question to be made.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: And be my trot if me have a noder patten for de counsell learned in the law, for to teach dem de reverence, dat vil be very great varke, but my diligence, and skill in dat matre, have no despaire, to effect in time dis great benefit, and dat vil make a de law flourish; and Englan a brave Englan, begar.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I won't doubt your abilityes, but I feare the capacity of the Gentlemen you undertake.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: But what will you look for now, for your paines Mounsieur? that is considerable.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar me looke for very mush, for tis mush paine, and tis brave ting, beside me looke for a statur of de brasse, in de pallace yard, ven me goe out of dis varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: You will deserve it as a rare patriot; but what manner of reverence would you have the grave lawyers to Imitate, you must consider their robes:

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Observe a me.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Such a reverence under your favour, would not become men of their gravity, one alwayes lookes for a Coranto after it, and provokes a man to whistle, or sing when he sees it, and makes one thinke still, what you would have a moneth, a little too much of the activity.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you no understand de matre, vere is your breine? dere is noting in de varle like a dat motion, for de Ientillman, and for de Ientilvoman.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p:
Yes by your leave sir there is something
else that is as good for them.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: I vil tell you now, begar, here is a de kinsman dat is a me, and he live here very much time, before he come, dey vent in vid deir toes, and hold der cloke just a dere, and de hat so, fie, le diable! and now dey valk vid deir toes out for brave genty, you call dat a de splay foot, but me vonder dat de Lady no come, begar me no use to dis patience, and de vaite, pray tell you Madam dat me have autre busines vid de Lor, and de autre Lady have de use of my foot begar.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Oh Monsieur by no means.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Let us prevaile.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Tis no good you hold a me, begar, me no stay two minute to save a your soule, dat is de resolution of de Cavalier de France.— Exit

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Would any man beleeve there should be so much folly in this Cubit square?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Do you think he is a French Dancer? let that answer you, and wonder he has no more Caprichios. But these Ladies are very tedious, we must have this Lecture put down.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: They are more like to purchase Gresham Colledg, and enlarge it for publick Professors, you may live to see another University built, and only women commence Doctors.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But now we talk of learned women, you have been acquainted with Mistris Voluble, has she the abilities the women talk of? they say she is a Fortune-teller.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p:
She is for more then Artificiall White and Red, some think her guilty of the Black-Art, she has foretold so many strange things; she has had two Husbands, and prophesied long before, how,
and when they should give up the Ghost, if she be not a Witch she has the more wrong, for she is beleev'd a devillish cunning woman.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Possible!

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: There's not a Lady with child but consults her Astrology, whether it shall be male or female; and the waiting women how long they shall keep their maidenheads, and who shall father the first borne, the Master or the servingman; she is held a Sibill in the City, and tells oraculously whether the Husband or the Wife shall die first, how, when, and where, and all this sometime by observation of the hand, or forehead; she can see a maid through a maske, and is excellent at stolne goods, for she can see a theefe through a millstone as well as a conjuring glasse; in brief, she is held prodigious at Divination, and most specially seldome failes in her Judgment of the two destinies, Matrimony, and Hanging, this I have heard Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Sr William Your Servant, Master Newman? that's he.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Jeere him soundly.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What Gentlemen are these?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: He has betraid his ignorance already, he does not know us.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: What, not the Major, and the Minor?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Not the Major, nor the Minor.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Cede majori Sir, Cede majori.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Parce minori Sir, Parce minori.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Here will be a fine conclusion from these premises, and they were worth considering.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: These two are wits.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Are they your wits? Pray heaven you may not lose 'em.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: If you love wit observe a little, and if I do not make you laugh, never laugh while you live.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: You shall here how I will jeere Newman, my Rivall now; such wit, wit of the last Edition: Let me have faire play, and these most ingenious friends of mine shall be judges.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: I think so, 'twill passe time till the Ladies come.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Mr Newman, you are a pretty Scholler, pray what is wit?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: A thing you want.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: A very pretty Probleme.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Will you or these Gentlemen be bound to understand me?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, that's a clinch, to understand me.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: A clinch?

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: I understand none.

sp.speaker: Simpl.
sp.p: Oh sir, a palpable clinch; Ha, ha, ha, aske my friend.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Is that your opinion?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: There's another clinch yfaith, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Pray sir, what is't a clock?

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: The mystery of this?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What is a clinch sir, do you know what 'tis?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
I neither know, nor care what 'tis, so I laugh, and sweare 'tis a clinch, that's disgrace and reproach enough to any man. With what ease can we cry up our own wit and anothers down, only by
saying that's a clinch. I think I ha jeerd him.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Oh the waies to wit are much shortned in these latter times, 'tis a picant age.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They have a gunpowder-plot to blow up sence; pray Gentlemen take truce with your spleenes, and the wisest of you three informe me what is wit; you have; no patience to heare me; or if you will not define it, speake something that is witty, and in fashion.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Ile tell you then:

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: You speak English to be understood, O base!

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What language is your wit?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: English, but elaborate, for example— now beat up your kettle drums.

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: Sir, if my opticks faile not, I have read
Each mystick line within your brow, my Genius
Is much exalted at your gaudy Phisnomy;
Shal's to the house of mighty noise and surfets,
There tinct our souls with bloud of purple grape?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What's all this?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I thought you were ignorant.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Give him the Paraphrase.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: All this is, he remembers perfectly he has seene you before.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: And desires you but to go to the Tavern, and drink a pint of wine; here's language!

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What a deale of Embroydery is spent upon I am glad to see you well; How long has this been a vulgar language? You would court a Mistris rarely in this Cabale.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: But how shall a man beget such high conceits?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Have you a desire to know Sir William? shall I tell him?

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer
sp.p: If he will make it a secret.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Why, turne your selfe round as fast as you can, and the first things you speak, your head being dissie, will be these.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What a beavy of Buffoons have we here?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: We are at your mercy Gentlemen; but you that had a patience to expect so long, cannot want vertue to forgive, since we had no intent to make so great a trespasse; where's Monsieur Galliard?

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Madam, he's gone, something displeas'd you had no more regard to a Gentleman of his quality; his time was pretious, and some other Lords and Ladies expected him.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: His absence will admit of easie pardon, 'tis a most superstitious foole; what Gent. are these?

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: They are things were meant by nature, Madam, a cure for melancholly, we have had such sport and non-sence with 'em

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: We shall lose time upon 'em, please you, wee'l take a turne i'th Gallery.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Mistris Lucy be tender-hearted to these Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They are only fit for your compassion.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: They are worth your acquaintance, Master Newman knows 'em; have not their wits a pretty edge?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Dismisse your Beagles I shall beat you all three else, and monstrously, indeed I shall; be rul'd, and keep your wits warme, I shall sling out like winter.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I thank you sir and you be in earnest; I
protest Major, and Minor, the man's in wrath, away.
How now Iames.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: I am glad I ha found you sir, your mother's come to town, she rode behind me.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Not too loud, where is she? I would not have it known till she have other cloaths, and better breeding.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: She's at your Lodging sir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Mistris Voluble, my mother's come by directions, mum, and make haste; sweet Mistris Lucy, I beseech you take it not unkindly if I depart.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: By no means noble sir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: This is my man that has brought me newes out of the Country forsooth.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: None of your Tenants dead I hope?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Some are Coppyholders, and I hope you wish me no harme, but I vow 'tis not my fault that I must take my leave so abruptly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: You have a cheerefull licence sir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: As I hope to make new Leases, and sell a hundred Acres of wood this Terme, I am very sorry, but I will waite upon you in the Evening. Noble Mr. New.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Ha, ha, that's a clinch.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I am your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Another Clinch I protest. Ex. Sim:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Now we have opportunity I preethee Mrs Voluble for my sake tell him his Fortune; I have been a sutor to know your destiny.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: It will be a favour, it was in my ambition to desire it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Lady desires your presence in the gallery.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I must observe her command, but you may satisfie the Gentleman in my absence, and Mr: Newman when you know how the starres have determined of you, make not me a more stranger.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I shal be onely fortunate to be yours.
Now Mistris Voluble, if you be acquainted with my starres, and know what fortune they decree me, I stand full prepared; what lines are in my forehead, you observe so?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Pray let me see your hand.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Freely command it.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Some that doe make a trade of fortune-telling (which is beneath my practise) flatter mea for their base end of profit, Ile be plaine.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Truth loves no other habit, you prepare me to give you the more faith.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Tis very strange, but this is most propheticall, you are—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: In love.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: 'Tis very likely.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: It may not prove so lucky, love is a melancholy businesse.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I thinke it be. Is this all you can tell by your art?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You would know your destiny.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What please my starres and you?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Take this for oracle then, you will do something in a melancholy humour will endanger your neck.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: My necke? shall I be hang'd? better the witch were burn'd.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Fare you well Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: A pox a your prognostick, she has put me
Into a sweat, and I doe more than halfe

Beleeve she is a witch, or worse, in a melancholy humour; must I doe something to endanger my necke? unth? I shall put my selfe into a desperate melancholy with thinking on't; I will be mercy, 'tis time to laugh and sing, thoughts doe not vex me to a new tune, ther's no way but to a Taverne, Ile seeke out company.

lg.l: Love by your leave a while, and lazy folly,
Sacke is the Antidote to melancholy.

div.head: Act. III. Scaena. I.
div.stage: Enter Simpleton, Mother (in riding cloathes) Mrs. Voluble, fames.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I Have obeyed you sonne, but I shall never fadge with these things you talke of.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Then y'are an asse, every childe can doe it.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I, if I had been a Gentlewoman of a child, much might ha been done.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
Alas after a little time, you wil take pride every day of your selfe; I wonder this wench
comes not! what? your sonne has a care of you, and 'tis never too late to learne to be a Lady; this maide I commend to you, is a very rare dresser to a pinne, and will keepe your linnen with all variety of sweet bagges and powders, that can be imagined; and for your rich gownes, she will preserve 'em with the new fashion-sereclothes, and make them outlast Egyptian bodyes.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: But must my old Mistris be a Lady? that will be fine ifaith.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: The Taylour has taken measure for a Lady I am sure, and three or foure yards of Sattin, more than will serve for a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Then she mun be kirstned, and call'd Madam.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Peace and harken to my Landlady.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Besides she has the rarest receits to destroy moathes, and such a soveraigne medicine against fleas, that your maides need never to squeak as if they were ravish'd, peeping into their smocks before they go to bed.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: That will be fine.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: The wench I tell you on, knowes how to consume Cornes too, and for fidelity about your box of teeth, false haire, your glasse eye.—

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My Mother has two eyes of her owne, but that one squints.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
Then for all manner of Caudles, Aleberries, Possets, and preserves in all kinds, and should you lye in this maid will be the most diligent creature about warming of cloaths, and for brothes and gellies most excellent, and for all strengthners of nature; then if any of your women be to apt to conceive any thing that is ill,
she hath her drinkes of retention, and expulsion— but Madam

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: She is no Lady yet.!

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Sir I speake what I foresee, and therefore among our selves, Madam agen, this maid is very discreet, you will know what that meanes, not troublesom when your Ladiship would be private, nor suffer any else to trouble you, and beside she will never be in love, which is no small matter for a waiting woman; she is here already— Enter Nice .Mrs. Nice you are fortunate to be recommended, to attend this, (but a Gentlewoman yet.).

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: She is too fine.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Hold your prating, and heare my Landlady, have not you clothes to come home?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: I shall think my starres have been carefull of me, if I may have the happinesse to shew my duty to so noble a Lady.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: She calls me Lady too.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: They know what will become on you.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Oh that I could speake so gainely; I am but new come out of the Country, but if you please to be as good as your word, I will doe the best I can, to be thankfull, as they say.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My mothers very raw, you must coddle her, you will have but a foule hand with her, doe you thinke she will ever come to any good? the truth is, I am asham'd on her, and therefore be not a knowne that she is my mother, till you ha' disciplin'd her, she must live very privately.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How shall her name, person and estate be publish'd? do not you meane to have her a Lady?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: By any meanes sir, and let me be one of her Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I have it; do you observe the maid I commended to her? She is a Gentlewoman alwaies bred among Ladies, and knows how to talk, and carry her self, before any Knight or Lord in the Court: What, if for the more expedite way to your mothers instructions this wench should take upon her sometime to be her Mistris, and in her name, before strangers, exercise some pride and courtship? 'tis a neerer way by example than precept to arive at any thing; and by observing her Fashion, Garbe, and Language, your mother may be sooner ripe for a Ladiship by at least two months, beside all the rules she may receive from us in private.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Admirable! My mother is a towardly old woman.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Old? you do not know how painting may transforme Age; and the wench is not so young as she seems; howsoever this will be only to strangers, and you may with more reputation own her for your mother among Gallants, 'tis but saying she was married at twelve, and you pop'd into the world before thirteen.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I will leave her to your tuition, and this Gentlewomans education.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Then 'tis thus Madam, come hither Nice.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Iames, thou shalt wait upon me to my Mistris when thou hast better cloaths.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: I have a new suite coming up from top to toe.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
Ile never live in the Country agen, such another clod was I when I came to London; mother
you must be dutifull, 'tis for your own good; but do you heare Landlady, have you spoke the powerfull word to my Mistris? Shall I have her from Newman?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I have read his destiny, and if things hit with his credulous nature, he will make himself uncapable of her affection; you are the next in preferment, never feare it, and leave your mother to our method and government, we will both edifie, and Ladifie her.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: With all my heart: buoy Lady mother.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: If please you wee'l withdraw; you must be secret Iames. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Manly (in Leisters habit) the two Ieerers meet him.

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer:
sp.p: What have we here?

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: The Ghost of Leister?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.l: Thus I have seen him painted,
'Tis some humorous Gentleman.

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: A proper fellow?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: It is not dark enough; how they gape at me?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Let's make sport with him, he shews admirably by twilight, he has not travelled far sure; such a shape would get money in Bartholmew Faire.

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: Are you a high German sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis a Fencer; did you not heare of a Swisse that came over to be beaten at eight severall weapons?

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p:
By your favor sir, no, 'tis no high German, those breeches are not worne in Switzerland,
there is something of the codpiece—

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: 'Tis not His Majesties Operatour for the Teeth, that hangs about Fleet-bridge.

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: He's not so hansome.

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Were not you one of the brothers that guarded the Dyall at Bow Church, and us'd to put Cheapside in mind of their quarters?

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: No, he wants a Pollaxe; do you think he came not off some Conduit?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: I am sure he came not off o'th' saltseller, He is a size too tall.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: These rogues will draw a Regiment of Prentices about me presently, and then shall I be apprehended for some sea monster, and thrown into the Thames at the next Staires, to shew their worships how well I can swim— have you any thing to say to me?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: 'Tis English that he speaks, he is one of us.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am one that will venture to beat you both in the same language, if you leave me not the sooner.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: 'Tis some that skulkes in this disguise for debt; we'l say we are Officers, and pretend to arrest him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay then have at you bandogs—
sp.stage: Enter Newman, and Gentlemen, (their swords drawn.)
sp.p: A reskue?

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: Hold.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Down with the Bayliffes, arrest a Gentleman in the Kings high way— Ex. Manly

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: So, so, he is escap'd. Ex. Gent.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
You cursed tadpoles, cannot a Gentleman
walk i'th' streets, but such Tenterhookes must catch him by the cloak?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Noble Master Newman, we are your servants; do not you know us? we are no officers.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Ha? If my opticks erre not, I have read
Each mystick line within your brows,
Ye shall both—

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Have our skins cut into measures.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: To the Taverne with me.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: We will be drunke together.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: You shall command us..

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: At my new Taverne where the wine shal flow as at a Coronation; fifty Fiddles, and a noise of Trumpets come along with me; you two shall send your tickets out for wenches.

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Of all complexions, and degrees, from the Madam Alamode, to the humble Wastcoteere. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I beseech you Mrs Lucy make not me the Author, I affect Mr Newman, but this I receiv'd from good intelligence.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I am miserable; I did not think his nature could degenerate into so wild a change, it is some witchcraft, I must grieve for him though I dare not shew it.

sp.speaker: Fo.
sp.p: Ther is a report, I would be loath you should name me in't, but they confidently say; I dare not justifie upon my knowledge, that he has kild—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Good heaven defend; then I am more undone.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Nay, these are the fruits of wine and surfets; I did not see him bleed, but I heard it from a man of quality, and one that had been Collector in the Parish, who told me for certaine that Mr Newman did kill him.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Whom? my afflicted heart.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: It was an Officer that was slaine.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: The more unpardonable.— Where?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: In the Parish of Alhallowes Barking, the Bell man never dawnd since, comming drunk out of a Taverne at twelve— he made no more adoe— there was not such another dog within the Wals; it waited upon the foresaid Bell-man a nights in His Majesties service, to waken the Parish, and all day was hir'd out by a Blind-man, that beg'd, with a Bell about his neck.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Is that all the murder he has committed?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: All? you do not consider the blind Begger that's undon by't, or who shall carry the Lanthorne at midnight, to light Gentlemen to the best Ale, and a Bawdy-house; but for my part Ile be no evidence, if the City will suffer such an injustice within their Walls I can be silent, and think.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Would this were all the danger, but I feare since he took up this rudeness and strange carriage he may deserve more sorrow.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I love not to meddle in other mens affairs, but I know something.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I prethee tell me all.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p:
The Taverne he frequents he has made his Theater at his own charge to act intemperance; o're the great Roome be uses to be drunk in, they say, he has built a heaven, a Players heaven,
and thence a Throne's let down, in which, well heated, successively they are drawn up to the clouds to drink their Mistris health, while the mad mortals adore their God of Grape, and gaping look like earth that's chap'd with heat, although before within three minutes they were drench'd.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Dost know that place?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You shall excuse me, I know nothing.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Prethee be not so cautious, I am his friend, and pity him; if for my sake thou woo't but find him out, and tell him I desire to change but a few words, trust me, I may amply requite this service.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You must then keep secret what I undertake, Ile do't. Be cautious to whom you speake, we must be circumspect. I will go off invisible. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Monsieur Galliard, my Lady expects you.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar me no like a dat reverence, me vil change a dat:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: 'Tis the French fashion as you taught Me Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Ouy, tis de French fashion, but de French fashion is alwaies to change, and dis reverence displease a me very mush, because you go back, back vid your buttock, as if some vod take you by dat, to vat me vil give a no name.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Monsieur Galliard my Ladie will be here presentlie.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Sweet Mrs Lucie.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Dat de reverence is no good of de man, me must change dat too; by me trot me doubt dat dis great business vil almost break a my braine,
dis great varke, and before a maske of de King and de Queene, me can eate a no meate, no drinke, no sleepe, and me growe so very a leane, vid de contemplation, a so much, by my trot de privy counsell is no so much troubled as me be vid dis, oh, le Diable! deirs is noting, dey sit all the vile dey doe deir busines, me bissey bo'te head, and de foot cap a pie, in de french tune, and dat is great matre begar.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: You esteeme it highly Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me tell you, and me tell you no tale, tis great matre to make a de Lor, to make a de Lady, to make a de Gentleman, to make a de Gentilvoman, and de autre man to dance, and to make a de good reverence, for begar dat vil make a de King, de great kin in de varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: How can that be Sir?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me tell you, ven dey are so bissey, to learne a de dance, dey vil never tinke of de Rebellion, and den de reverence is obedience to Monarchy, and begar obedience is ale de ting in de varke.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I'le sweare your state affaires ly in your foot, and you are wiser there, than some heads are, and may be a president for after ages; but what musick would you governe the people by?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar by de best french fidles can be got?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What thinke you of an Irish harpe, a state organ, or a passionate voyce to a lovers lute?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Des dull tings make a de men melancholique, and den dey tinke on de Devill, and de
treason, and do any ting dat is no good, but begar des french fidles doe fidle all deis tings out of deir head, vid such a Jearke, as ma foy make a dem so phantasticall, and make a dem as good subject, as any is in de France begar.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I must waite upon my Mother.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: She will be here immediately.—
She is not right yet.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Here be one of my coliers, Mounsieur Simplaton, say you no dat de french fidle make a de brave government in de varle?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I say any thing becomes a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Observe you dat? he have been but two are mont and he say any thing, dat is very brave? he have de grand understanding in de foot; tell a me, ven you heare a de little fidell, vat is your tinke? is your head no free from de treason, and plot of de rebell, as your leg? begar you no stand upon de ground for Joy of de Coran, de Cerebran, de Marquiss, de Mountague, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: My Lady.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me be your humble servant Madam, and stay one two tre houre.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I am now ready for you Mounsieur, come Lucy the practise of the last he taught us.

div.stage: Lady and Lucy dance, Mounsieur singing, and correcting them in tune.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The Gentleman you expect Sir William is come.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Madam prepare your selfe for mirth, 'twill be a sight beyond the pageants.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Wee'l not be seen at first, Lucy withdraw.— Exit Lady and Lucy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What meanes this flourish? have you a play in hand?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: To bid your excellence welcome to this lodging.
Fore Jove he lookes prodigiously, vouchsafe
Us th' honor of your hand.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vat Antick be dis?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: One of the supporters of the Brewers Armes.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, does he take upon him to be a Prince too, and will he speake?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: These Ladyes have ambition to kisse your hand, and have a great desire to know, how fares the campe at Tilbury, and please your Excellencie.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: 'Tis one of Arthurs Knights of the round Table.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: With his circular sippets; would you thinke that a pigmy poison'd should swell thus?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am betraid, there's no retreat with honour, I must be confident.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Laugh and Jeere him hansomely.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Oh that the Major, and the Minor had been here now, they would teeze him ifaith, Mounsieur, aske that Maypole and he can dance.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Plait il Mounsieur? a la Galiard, de Goran, la Princesse, le Buckingham, heigh!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Put up your rosin, and your catsguts
presently and be gon, or I shall finde a grave for you in the pocket of my sleeve, and this shal be your winding sheet.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me no play dat lesson, pocket de sleeve, dat is no tune de France, poket, le grand pock:— (Manly offers to strike him )pardonne moy Mounsieur: me put up my fidell and be gon, adieu Madam, Serviteur gentilhomes; pocket de sleeve? Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But I must not seeme angry, Lady, my businesse is to you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Businesse to me?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am bold to present a sute to you, I confesse it was not made by a French Tailor, I can make a leg and kisse my hand too after the fashion of my cloaths, this serv'd in those honest dayes, when Knights were Gentlemen, and proper men tooke the walls of dwarfes; here's a belly peece, that lookes like armour, with what comelinesse may a man unbutton his dublet, when he seemes to take the wall to make urine? your sleeve so neere your nose, with a handkerchiefe, which I take out thus with a grace, after Emunction, I put up agen, with the corianders hanging out, Geometricall breeches in severall slises, in which a man is not asham'd of his thighes, nor hides his bow leggs, which at the bottome surrounded with points make him look like a rough-footed Pigeon, these things were worne when men of honor flourish'd, that tam'd the wealth of Spaine, set up the States, help'd the French King, and brought Rebellion to reason Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: So they doe now.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Peace pepper corne; and all this at lesse charge than a masque comes to now, with the rare and new invention of hobbiehorses; which of our two habits (be you Lady, but the indifferent Judge, and squint not,) is the more grave and manly, his leane upper chinne, or this goodly promontory? my Trunkes with a round walke pav'd with gold and silver, or your trouses, cut close to your dock, and drawne on with a screw? in which if you venture but halfe a crowne, lookes like a poltisse, or a swelling in the groine; your habit is phantasticall as the time, you squirt into your dublet, which you weare so carelesse as you had not button'd it since you came from a bawdy house, where men of this garbe, coming from the stewes, march with that gravity as they came from a conventicle, so soberly they would carry it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I see whoring was equall in all times, onely the carrying of it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why that's all?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: But surely I doe wonder, how my Grandfather could kisse my Grandmother, or embrace in that strange apparell.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: They made a shift Knight, or else your wise worship had not been here; but that I want so much beard, I could shew how your Grandfather stroak'd his three or foure handfull of haire, to the terrour no doubt of the standers by, and could stab I warrant you, with his two handed beard then, as well as you with your dagger beard now. It was never a good time since these cloaths went out of fashion; oh, those honourable dayes and persons!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I pray inlarge your selfe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To have seene but a St. Georges feast then.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Why, what difference sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: When they were install'd, to see the twenty mile to Windsor strow'd with blew-coates, feathers and cognizances, as they do country townes with boughes, and flowers for Princes Entries, and not to go privately in a coach, with a page and a barber to cut off charges.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: How doe you like this Gentleman, Is't not a pretty humour?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Then you should have the best knight of the Countrey, with the ragged staffe on their sleeves.

lg.l: The Beare, the Boare, and Talbot with his tuskish white,
Oh so sore that he would bite,
The Talbot with his Tuskish white
Soudledum Soudledum;
The Talbot with his Tuskish white Soudledum, bell.
The Talbott with his Tuskish white
Oh so sore that he would bite
Orebecke soudledum, sing orum bell.

sp.p: Every Knight had his hundreds, and these would take up all the Tavernes in the Towne, be drunke to the honour of their Lords, and rather than not pay their reckoning, pawne their chains, though they pawn'd something for them the night before, and such merry catches then, as

lg.l: The Hart loves the high wood,
The Hare loves the hill,
The Knight lov'd his bright sword,
And the Lady lov'd her will.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: So the Ladies do still.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: It may be so, but for your Knights bright Sword 'tis at pawn, or at home in his Armory; then we had, God blesse the Duke of Norfolke, there was a jeast, and another Song.

lg.l: The great Choe bent,
The little Choe bent,
Sir Piercy leigh under the line;
God blesse the good Earle of Shrewsbury
For he's a good friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: He's very confident.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Alas, he is compel'd to't.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: How do you like this Mrs Lucy, is he not a pretty ill-favour'd Gentleman in this habit?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: He sings rarely.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: No question he can dance too, in that disguise he lookes like famous Cardell the dancing. Master in Queen Elizabeths time, I have seen his Picture.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And he with your Worships favour, was held a wise man, and for his gravity he might have been Treasurer, he went with that setled and solid Pian-piano.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p:
And when he danc'd a measure, you should have had him with his Rapier, short Cloak,
his black Cap, and his white Feather, his single and double, both backward and forward, with that excellencie—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And now he must be in Cuerpo, or like a fellow on the ropes, or a Tumbler when he shoots his body through a hoop; there was musick then, and a Heaven and Earth, beyond your braules, or your Mountague, with a la, la, la, like a Bachanalian dancing the Spanish Morisce, with knackers at his fingers.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: It must needs be a rare sight.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He plaid to himself on a grave Lute, or a modest Citterne, with a politick quill, far beyond your Geofrey fiddle, or your French kit, that looks like a broken fagot stick, at the biggest, and sounds as if it had got the French disease, when it snivels out a Coranto, or so hoarse with a cold, as if some great base Fiddle had silenc'd it.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: What misery is it, the Monsieur is gone now? here had been a French Duell.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But had you seen my Lord Loftie dance the Galliard, with such capers, such half capers, such turns o'th toe, and above ground, you would have sworn 'em sound for nine Generations, and for Lavaltoes, La, la, la, &c. and then the Lady.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: How did he use her?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: With wonderfull skill, he put his right arme about her, and took her lest hand in his, and then he did so touze her with his right thigh and legg, and list her up so high, and so fast, and so round—

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: As what I pray, be curteous.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Marry as soon as he had ended his dance she would lye down as dead as a swing'd chicken,
with the head under the wing, so dissie was she, and so out of breath; and all these wonders were extant Knight when this old Cap was new.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Is not this very fine sport Madam?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, y'are welcome; pray excuse me, if being prepar'd for some folly, your garbe and person seem'd at first ridiculous; you have chang'd my opinion, and there wants but such a noble leader to reduce, and make this habit fashionable; it shews a proper man, and if I were worthy to advise, or could lay an obligation upon you, I should take it for an honour if you would often visit me in these ornaments, I like 'em infinitely, and the Wearer shall be ever welcome; please you wee'l walk and talk a turn in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You too much grace me Madam.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.l: How's this?
I have wound my self into a pretty business,
She neglects me.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: In my judgment 'tis an indifferent pretty fellow, but that his cloaths are out of fashion.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: They are most becomming; I do not like your new phantasticall shapes, that transforme a man from his masculine aspect; you appear to me like a Jackanaps; there's a waste, and a Long lane cut close to your hanches. Exit.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
Hum! she takes after the old one, I will try and shift my self, if the mother be taken with the habit in Qu. Elizabeths daies, why may not the daughter affect that in K. Jameses, and so the humor run in a bloud? I am resolv'd; she loves singing too, I am furnish 'with Ballads, o'my conscience
this will do't; Ile fit her with a fashion, and about it presently. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: They are here agen, and laugh at me: How familiar the Turtles are?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Wee'l taste some aire i'th' garden, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: So, so, if I did love this widow for her self, what a case were I in? but I must not sit down thus, and something must be thought on for my honour. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. IIII. Scaene I.
div.stage: Enter Mistris Voluble, and Nice, (having a Jewell.)

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: SO, so, thou dost carry it excellently, it spreads like a Proclamation, what a rich widdow lies at my house, her wealth, and wit, must be exercis'd.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: She must not appeare to be herself yet but in private, and the Chiause her Son has bestow'd this Jewell upon me for expedition, for he dares not yet acknowledge her; she wonders at herself now she is painted, & sweares in her conscience she looks by her glass like one of foure and twenty, and simpers, and licks her leatherne lips as she had eaten Marmalade.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Sir William has heard of her, and (upon some affront, as I conjecture receiv'd from my Lady) has writ to me, and articled already to dispose her affections, I expect him every minute.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: He will discover us.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: He shall never see thee act her part.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Do you thinke he can affect her?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Courtiers do not marry into the City for love, and this Farmers wife has wealth enough to Enter Simpleton, and James, (with his cloaths. )buy a Ladiship; here's the gull, away and be diligent. Exit Nice.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: They'l fit you as well as my self for whom they were made in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How now sir, preparing for a race?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Is no body else with you? Do not enquire what stratagem is in hand, there be more waies to catch a Mistresses heart; how does my mother?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: She is pretty apt for one of her yeares: I can tell you news, there is a Knight about her already.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: She shall have him.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Not with your favour if a greater person Interpose, I have so much care of her honour, now she is my charge.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Mistris Voluble, here's a Footman, lac'd all over, enquires for you, he serves a French Lord, he saies he must needs speak with you, he has a letter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: What if this Lord come hither for the same purpose?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
Tis too much happinesse; Ile not be
seen thus, nor let my Mother appeare in her roughcast, use the Footman kindly, if his message concerne us, away— Exit Vol.
And will this Fashion become me, dost thinke? I prethee tell me some old stories in to'ther raigne, thou canst talke and make me ready too.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Ah sir, I knew a time, when two and twenty yeares was but a merry Christmas, nothing but Ambassadors, Masques, Playes, Entertainements, Hawking, Hunting, Winter and Summer, New-Market and Roiston mourne now, ha! had you seen the Court fox'd upon Gouries night, and the Gunpouder treason began then; oh we had rare sport, and then every body was knighted, they hardly lest a Gentleman in those dayes; and afterward they got a tricke of making Lords.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I know not that, but they hardly left a Knight, man, woman, and childe were made right honourable.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Right honourable, right worshipfull, and well beloved, I have heard that in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: But the fashion of welbeloved is left off, for we doe not now love one another.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But had you no misfortunes?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Faith Sir, a rainy day was the worst, and that had but made the ground more soluble the next day for hunting.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: No complaints James?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p:
Oh yes sir! I hard a Gentleman complaine mightily that he had lost the highest flying tassell gentle, that ever was seene, another that he had
prick'd his grey Nag, that was an excellent buckhunter; a third, that he had fretish'd his best hound, Beauty, and that Lilly was kill'd at a Bay a stag-hunting, it had almost cost the Genleman his life.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: And what else James?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: By my troth sir, a Gentleman waiter, that shall be namelesse, removing a pasty of Venison, spilt it all, on a new satten doublet, and spoiled it utterly, there was such laughing, but his Master being gracious gave him a sute for his doublet, I thinke it was a Knight; but the Knight market is risen now.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I and the Lord Market too, James.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: And please your worship, they say, the Herald would not make a Gentleman now, under ten pound.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Oh yes, they'l take reason to my knowledge, and give the prettiest phantasticall armes, I have all the colours of the Rainebow in my new coate, every foole may be a Gentleman of three generations now.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I can derive my selfe knave three descents under your ancesters.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Then thy children may write themselves knaves of blood, take that upon my Heraldry; but had not you brave songs then James?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p:
In those dayes was the quintessence of ballads, you went to schoole with 'em, I remember and learn'd no other bookes, I shall never forget the Lord of Lornes sonne in Scotland and the false steward, to the tune of greene sleeves, those were the dayes indeed, oh there was then such a company for dancing singing and fooling, I doe
not meane the wits, for fooling is another thing cleare from it; It does so bravely in company, when there is a great many that care not for wit, and pleases better than all the wit in the world; and then there was such brave jeasts, at the death of a Stag, and Buck; to throw blood up and downe, upon folkes faces; the very Footmen and Pages understood those Jeasts then; there was a time; and the Landerers were as well Employed in a progresse then as now, and the Surgeons got as much by 'em too; oh, I shall never forget those times.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: So, so, how doe I looke in this transformation? will any body know me dost thinke? Mistris Lucy, shall have the first sight of my shape; some body is gone into the dining roome, let us out at the backe doore James. Exeunt.

div.stage: (Enter Nice. (dressing the Mother, painted) (at another Doore) Mrs. Voluble.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: 'Tis well done Nice to be carefull about your Mistris.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I am giving her some instructions about dressing, and was saying, she must not goe above once to court in black, it would be very scandalous without intermixing colours, in her petticote, sleeves, and stomacher, and the colours now in fashion are blew, pincke, and incarnadine, yellow is much worne too.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: But 'tis very materiall, what lace you wil choose, as silver and gold for blew, (That's a court maxime) and plaine silver for incarnadine, single or mixt will serve for pincke colour.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I shall never remember all this.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: It is your Gentlewomans duty to remember.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Let me alone Madam. When you will keepe house, a long handkercheife, or a round one with a quaife tied under your chin, and a little haire curl'd, with a black taffata hood, or white sarsenet.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: When you pretend to have a cold, you must shew no haire, but weare a forehead cloth, with a pinner over that, these cloathes are much worne by old Ladyes, with which they binde downe a peece of searecloth upon their forehead, to keepe wrinckles in obedience. How is her haire?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: That little that she has is crazie.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: She has enough to curle, and you have the discretion to know what proportion is to be left out, according to the latitude of her face; and to be curl'd with pinnes and orrice pouder, which will neither hurt nor breake it, and then in the Morning to let the combe passe through it once, and open it, between a curle and a freeze, and draw up some of the curles with a bodkin within the other haire.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: My haire will never indure all this.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You must endure more, if you meane to be a Lady of fashion, and attractive; where be the pendants?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Must she not weare a Feather?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Not without a diamond bodkin; have you no Jewels?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Yes, In the knot of my handkerchiefe.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Oh fie, you must buy a Cabinet. What's here? a Toad stone, two Turkies, sixe thumbrings, three Aldermens seales, five Gemmals, and foure Deaths-heads; these are Alehouse ornaments— Yet these Diamonds are tollerable, and these Pearles will make a half Chaine.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Would she were hangd in the fellow, condition we had the rest.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: They must be changd, but Nice may weare these til you get new, they will serve to practice in. (Knock within.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: There's a Coach at doore.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Ile pawne my ability the French Lord, 'tis about the time I gave directions to his Footman; for his entertainment, you must take upon you the rich widdow, and be you carefull to observe Mrs Nices Language, garbe, and behaviour, to men of his quality; your Rings and Jewels upon her will credit the cause, and person he comes to visit, which is your self, but under a vaile. Ile prepare his Lordship. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: This is all for your instruction; these rings fit me excellent well, and hereafter you may take pride upon you by my example.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I hope I shall learne in time; but I shall be more than a Lady if I marry with a Lord.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Alas, I am but the Lady in the Play.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Now you put me in mind, I have seen pretty harlotry Ladies in a Country Play, so proud, and so knavish, one would have sworn they had been women indeed.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p:
Hee's here, you must be modest, and observe your distance now; Is this the Lord? He
looks like an over-grown Monkey.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: What pretty foolish things some of these young Lords are?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Your Lordship is bountifull; that is she whom fame hath delivered to you; your honour may advance.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar dis rish viddow looke young as my selfe.

sp.speaker: Vol
sp.p: If my eyes be not in a mist this is the French Dancer.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vat is your name?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: He means to catechise her.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I shall be happy if your Lordship please to own me by the title of your servant.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You must learne to complement thus— 'Tis Galliard sure.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: She kisse very vel begar, she have de Alamode touch of de lip ma foy; can you dance Madam?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I am now confirm'd.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Will he kisse me too?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vat is she?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman that attends me for the present.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Dat is a de reverence for de divel, she look like a de wihch Madam, but me tell you Madam, for me love you very mush in the little time, as any man in de varle; me be French Lor, and me have lodging in de autre street, Duke de Memorency my kinsman, and two tre hundred great Lors have lose deir head in France begar for no matre, and me flye to Englan to save a me neck by me trot.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Were you guilty of any treason?

sp.speaker: Gal
sp.p: No more begar than your little self.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: What is your estate?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar very grand estate in Orleance, me have two tre Lettre from de Cardinall, and he write a me, dat de King send for me to kiss his hand: Now as me vas in de resolution to take a de ship for France, me heare of you Madam in de Strand, and me very glad to marry you before me go presently.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Your Lordship is very briefe, but I find not my self enclin'd to crosse the Seas.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: The Sea, mary shield, Ile not see the salt water for any Lord in Christendome, I, Ile rather be no Lady.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Who, how now insolence, how dare you interpose?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Will you be ridiculous, and betray your self now?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you have de Gypsey complexion, and looke like de sign of-de Robin Hood and maid a Marian.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Robin Hood in thy face, does he maid a Marian me?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: She is not worth your Lordships passion, I shall teach you better manners.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you shall have mush need of dat.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: My Lord, you did aske me if I could dance.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: The wench has found him.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Dere is noting in de varle for de Lady, like a de understanding in de foot.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I cannot praise my own ability, but I admire the excellency of other Ladies, and should be fortunate to meet with some Master in the faculty, that would Instruct, and exercise me in private.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me love you de bettre for dat, begar no body exercise you in private but my self, me teach you Alamode de Court dance, hold up your litel fingre you command a my foot.

sp.speaker: Ni.
