sp.p: Your Lordship is too humble, it is an office would become one that is mercenary; I affect dancing infinitely, oh that we had but some musick here; la, la, ra. (She sings, Gal. draws out his Fiddle.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Tis comming out.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: What's that a bedstaffe?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: It is a French pocket-pistoll.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Will he shoot it oft here? I could never indure a gun. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gal
sp.p: Forboon, brave, ah, dat is like a de Princess, Allez.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: You shall not be so publick in your graces to me; conceale your Fiddle till some private opportunity.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me understand.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How does your Lordship like her? You have her in an excellent humour.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Kisse a me madam— hah? 'tis heaven? de Poet talke of de Nectar, begar here is it; me never drink de blanke or de Claret, so me have but two tre drop divine from your lip— Metresse speake a for me.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: The foole is extasied; in his worst condition he will serve for a husband; how he dances in a Net?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: He has money, and a Trade, he will serve wench.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: If me get dis rish widdow, me cozen 'em both begar.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Do you think he loves me indeed. Ex. Vol.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: You no tinke madam dat me be so hot in love, and do burne, dat my reine a do melt, as me vere in de oven, me need a go into de river presantly to coole and vater my heart, vere is de Mistresse de la Maison? Gone? dat is vel, dere is no honor like a dat, as you take a de litel aire in my Coach.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I have not been abroad to day, but I dare trust my self with your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Oh Madam, a vostre service, now if me get a de Priest all is perfect.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Be all these Trunkes hers?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: We ha not stowage enough for half, she is infinitely rich.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Hast thou prepar'd her?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I find her very apt, 'tis her only ambition to be a Lady, a French Lord has her in chase, but I have delivered your character, and what priviledge she may have by charter of her Knight.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: I long to see her, is she handsome?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: What she wants in beauty and breeding, she has in estate Sir.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: That, that's enough, I can have beauty in other places, and will exceed what I condition'd for, if I prosper. I will have this Widdow in spight.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How Sir William?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: To spight the Lady Beaufield, and her Magog that affronted me; I would lose no oportunity, a widdow must be taken in the pick; say I am come and commend me to the heavens, Ile make all good.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: To the heavens? will you dye before her?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: For that we must take our chance; thou shalt be sure of a good lease for thy life, and destiny agree upon us afterward.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Shall I direct you?

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Sha't be my evening, and my morning star. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You too much afflict your self Mistris Lucy, 'tis but some humour he put on to try the strength of your affection.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: He is lost; not for my sake, but for his own I pitty him, and I am confident, if I were so happy to speak with him agen, I should prevaile to win him to his first and noble temper; my end being so just, I could dispence with modesty to find him out, and perfect the act of charity.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You have imployd Formall, from whom you may expect to heare such an account, as may dry up your sorrows.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I see Sir you preserve your confidence.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I dare be just in your commands, and in a service you but smile upon, despise the censure of the world.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Saw you not the Knight since?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The sweet hopes that he swallow'd, to prepare me a ridiculous object to you Madam, was gall upon his stomack, when he found you had mercy on my confidence; he dares not converse with so unlick'd a beare, as this shape must present Enter Simpleton, and James .his criticall eye sight. What's here? one sent to affront me?

sp.speaker: Simp.

lg.l: When Robin came to Nottingham dery, dery down,
His dinner all for to dine:
There met him fifteen iolly Foresters,
Were drinking Ale, and Wine, hey down.

sp.p: Madam your most humble servant; there be other men, and manners, and garbes as fashionable in the eyes of discreet Ladies.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Have we got Adam Bell, and Clim o'th Clough?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: We be three, good Mr William of Cloudesly.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: 'Tis so.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: And how, and how shew matters Mistris Lucy? every mans Cap is not made of the same matter.
sp.l: Have you felt the wooll of Beaver?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: — Or sheepes down ever?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: — Have you smelt of the bud of the Rose?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: — In his pudding hose.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: — Or have tasted the bag of the Bee?
Oh so fine!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: — Oh so fond!

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: — Oh so brave!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: — Such a knave!

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: — Such a knave is he.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, this is most uncivill, and your rashnesse, beside the forfeit of your own discretion, will lay an imputation to wound my fame; within my presence, and beneath my roofe, which should protect all strangers, to affront a Gentleman that visits me—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Be bold sir, and presume you have my favour, you never appear'd handsome till this minute; beare up, your mirth becomes you rarely.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Dos't ifaith?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: What does my mother meane?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Spit o' thy hand, and clap me oth' shoulder Iames, the widow her selfe is in love with me.

lg.l: She cast an eye on little Musgrave
As bright as the summers sunne.

sp.p: I may turne o're the daughter to thee.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I would I had her in an Embroiderd clout.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sure my Lady is but in jeast.

lg.l: Shew me said he whose men ye be
That hunt so boldly here,
That without my consent do chase
And kill my follow Deere.—

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: His follow Deere?

lg.l: Ere thus I will out braved be
One of us two shall dye,
I know thee well an Earle thou art,
Lord Percy, so am I.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Thou Douglas?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
This Lady has but fool'd me all this while; make much of your new Antick Madam, I can shift into my selfe agen, and if that thing were worth my anger, or my envy, beate him;
you have a pretty humour, cherish it, and that William of the Wispe, till I visit you agen.— Exit

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: The Gentleman is jealous.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I protest Madam if it had hot been not your sake, and that it had been pitty to have spilt any blood, in your Dining roome, I would ha done something

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: In his breeches.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But I shall report your noblenesse abroad.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Doe not play the foole to much, I am out of the humour to laugh at you; he cannot leave me thus.— Exit Beau.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: This was no tricke to catch the old one.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: How came you into this habit Simpleton?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: By reading Ovids Metamorphosis, and to shew the variety of my wit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let me entreat you hold your feet together,— now you put me mind of a Smiths bellowes, your body is not all of a peece sure, but severall limbes thrust into severall pudding bags, you would shew terrible to the crowes in a wheat field, you are no living creature.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Perswade me to that, am I not sensible?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He that does that cure upon you, will deserve a chronicle; so desiring you would take home your flaile there, for here is like to be no thrashing worke, I commit you to the Barne, where like another Orpheus, you will draw the horse, and sheepe, to the melody of your voyce, and ravish all the Cowes in the Countrey, to heare you sing Packingtons pound.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: She has made a coxcombe on you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p:
Hum? I wo'not out o'the pit for all this, I
have another devise, and thou shalt assist me, if that faile, I'le dye a bachelor, and make thee my heire.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I shall but pray for your death sir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: Back agen, back agen quoth the Pindar,
The wrong way have you gon, &c.

div.stage: A Table, Stooles, Bottles of wine, and Glasses, set out by two Drawers.— then Enter Newman, the two Jeerers, Wenches, Musitians.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: So, so, I'le dance no more, a song, lets have a song now.

sp.speaker: 1 Wen.
sp.p: Take heed of the old ballads, eccliped, Like Hermit poore, eyes hide my love, or Panae in the brazen Tower.

sp.speaker: 2 Wen.
sp.p: Or the lamentable complaint of Ariadne, and Theseus, and the more lamentable for being so long.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Doe you heare Madam vertue, Lady modesty cannot you play your part?

sp.speaker: 1 Je.
sp.p: Not upon the violin.

sp.speaker: 2 Je.
sp.p: They are both for the Gambo.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You shall play the part of my Mistris, you must be witty then, and extreame coy and scurvy, in your answers; go behind that hanging, I will suppose it your chamber; now Boy the Song I made to the window, while I mustle my selfe with the fidlers, to bid my Mistrisse good morrow in the street, observe the conjuration.

lg.l: I conjure thee, I conjure thee, by thy skin that is so faire,
Thy dainty curled haire,
And thy favour and thy grace,
With the patches on thy face,
And thy hand that doth invite
The cold, dullest appetite,
— Appeare appeare,
Upon these termes I doe invite thee,
And if thou com'st I will delight thee.
If not so, I doe not care,
Though thy breasts be ne're so bare,
Roses rich, with shooe that's white,
Or thy Venus best delight,
If not touch thy softer skin
What care I for thee a pin,
Appeare appeare.
For to heare, and not to see
Is a dull flat history,
And to see and not to touch
If you thinke the last too much,
Know all woman's but one ioy
If we men not them enjoy,
Appeare appeare.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: She's not awake, play a ratling tune that may startle her; where's this whore? ha!—

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: She's gone.

sp.speaker: 2 Jer.
sp.p: Vanish'd? so he might have sung away his lungs.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: It may be, she is retir'd, for you know what Lady; come let us drinke.

sp.speaker: 2 Wench.
sp.p:
Was your Muse at all this expence
to the fidles? do you write to no other company sir?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Till they have my liveries; Ile maintaine 'em in songs, wind up your voyce agen.

lg.l: Thine eyes to me like sunnes appeare
Or brighter starres their light;
Which makes it summer all the yeare,
Or else a day of night:
But truely I doe thinke they are
But eyes, and neither sunne nor starre.
Thy brow is as the milky way,
Whereon the gods might trace:
Thy lips Ambrosia I dare say
Or Nectar of thy face:
But to speake truely I doe vowe
They are but womens lips and browe.
Thy checke it is a mingled bath
Of Lillyes and of Roses;
But here there's no man power hath
To gather loves fresh posies:
Beleeve it here the flowers that bud
Are but a womans flesh and blood.
Thy nose a promontory faire,
Thy necke a necke of land;
At natures gifts that are so rare
All men amaz'd doe stand:
But to the cleerer judgement those
Are but a womans necke and nose.
For foure lines in passion I can dye
As is the lovers guise,
And dabble too in Poetry
Whilst love possest, then wise
As greatest States-men, or as those
That know love best, yet live in Prose.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: The pure spirit of Sack in't.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: The wits Elixar.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: No jeering Gentlemen, I shall grow loud and break the peace.

sp.speaker: 2 Wen.
sp.p: These Gentlemen are for nothing but song and drink, I see no market all this while; Ile get me hence too; if please you, Ile see if I can find out my sister. Ex. 2 Jeer.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: There's but one stoole in the counting house, and Lady you shall stay till she returne; Gentlemen there's no life in you; I cannot do this roring and whoring handsomely; little thinks Lucy what Comrades I have got.

sp.speaker: 2 Wen.
sp.p: I have a pretious confidence in you Gentlemen, to trust my single modesty amongst so many.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What would you give to be ravish'd now? thou hast an excellent complexion for't.

sp.speaker: 2 Wen.
sp.p: Ravish'd? preserve the Gentlemans deare wits Sack I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You would not lose by it if he ravish you.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: another Song, and direct your voice to this Lady.

lg.l: I'de have her merry, laugh, and smiles
And then look grave and sad:
In every humour but a while,
Make love as 'tis, that's made
I'de have your dresse of sever all shapes,
Like Proteus carv'd, not he,
In humour a she coy Jackanapes
Then a grave Monkey be.
Discourse of all that comes to sence,
But speak none, yet still speak,
No matter here is no offence,
But to speake matter weak.
With thy soft voice sing me asleep,
Then startle me awake,
With Loves notes-passion make me weep,
Then merry for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Jeer. Mi.
sp.p: A discovery?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What new-found Land?

sp.speaker: Jeer. Mi.
sp.p: The Pigeon that left us hath been in another roome with Mr Formall my Lady Beaufields Gentleman Usher, there he sits like the picture of a Harry Soveraigne in a chaire, while she is picking on's pocket.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Fetch him, and his Fairy hither, but for his Mrs sake usher him with loud musick. Ex. Jeer.
Wee'l have some sport. (Flowrish.

div.stage: Enter the two Jeerers, and Formall.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Where's the wench?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: The wench has made an escape, she had a glimpse before and suspected me, but here's the wicked Elder.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What saies my wise Lucullus?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Sir, my business was to you, though I met a Remora that is already sunke, I was sent by a Gentlewoman, but no body must know it.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: We heare no business till he have wound up a bottle, and then he shall have audience.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: That's but your fee for entrance, your garnish only; come sir there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I hope you will conceale it Gentlemen.

lg.l: Why then let us drinke,
Away skurvy thinke,
And do't till we winke;
Which is just to be
So drunke not to see.
First Maudlin to weep,
Then after to sleep;
Why they let us drinke,
And do't till we winke,
Away skurvy 'thinke.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: What will become of me? would you and I Lady were in a back roome.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: So now speak my Lord Embassador, I know your soveraign Lady greets us well.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Alas sir, my Lady does not know of my comming; I would speak with you from one that shall be nameless, who thinks you are a debauch'd Gentleman, under the Rose, and desires to talk with you when you are sober: I would be loath to disgrace you before this good company, neither was I willing to tell her what I heard about your drinking and whoring.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: To the point.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: I, I, to the point.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: The principall matter then, and indeed my whole employment at this time to you is—

sp.speaker: New
sp.p: What in the name of circumspection?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You shall excuse me sir, silence is a vertue; but if you knew who sent me—

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: He would make a costive Statesman.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: It is sufficient one desires to speak with you, I name no time, nor person, I know my office; Mistris Lucy is not to be named at all times.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Mistris Lucie, I am her servant; come drink this narrow sea to her health, you must be drunk infallibly, Ile give a reason; I sweare by Muscadell That I do love her well; come yee Mermaids—

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Ile do you reason then; but is this Muscadell? Mr Newman has sworne; for my own part, Gentlemen, I desire it should go no further.

lg.l: I sweare by Muscadell
That I do love thee well,
And more than I can tell.
By the White, Claret, and Sack
I do love thy Black, black, black,
I do love thy black, black, black.
No Goddesse 'mongst them all
So slender, and so tall,
And gratefull too with all,
Which makes my sinews to crack
For thy black, black, black,
For thy dainty black, black.
So lovely, and so faire,
Though shaddow'd with thy haire,
So nimble, just like aire;
All these set me on loves wrack
For thy black, black, black,
For thy dainty black, black.
Thy kind and cunning eye,
When first it did espy,
Our love it did descry,
Dumbe speaking, what d'you lack?
Mine answer'd, thy black, black,
Thy dainty black, black, blacke.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Excellent!

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Now give Mr Formall his cup.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I have had the narrow sea, I cannot drink an Ocean.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: His t'other cup; you had my wench as I remember, and Ile prescribe you a pennance; there's another whore for you, drink to her and shee shall pledge.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, and set thy foot to mine.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You may trust your single modesty with him.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: For my own part, I had rather do things privately; come kisse me first— here's to thee, my flesh tingles—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: A word with you two Squiers.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Any thing for a shelter, I foresee a storm; and what is one Cat among so many Mastives?

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You are melancholly.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You lye, you that say nothing lye, if you be of his opinion.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Me thinks we are very merry.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: We are exceeding merry.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Have you discharg'd your Culvering? where's the paraquito?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I drunke it off.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: She is vanish'd too.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
Then we are our selves, and make me
your example; you know your Province Sirra, make ready for an Angell, sing the designe of honour, and of fancy. Ex. boy.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: But first in Phansie we will foole,
Pull off our Dublets, drinke more coole,
Our hats upon our heads not stay,
For each health wee'l throw them away
So Periwig, or Fringe, or Border,
The naked truth wee'l drink in order.
And to the Musick as they play
A Phansie Peece wee'l throw away,
Untill we are drein'd, can draw no more,
And the next day all cry therefore.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Off With Formalls Doublet, off with his Doublet, throw't into the fire, that's a good phansie; now he is Formall right.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I did not drink hard, for I am cold, the wench would keep me warme, she's a notable fire-drake; will it please you sir to go to the party?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Now does he betray what a Bawd he would be.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Does no body know where to get a Serpent with two legs that hath never a sting?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I have a great mind to drink a health in one of my boots.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I drink no beere glasses, if a shooe will serve turne—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: His shooe, my scabberd, a match.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: My glove.

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: His cap.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Fill brimmers, every man to his Mistris; now do not I like this phansie.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We ha don't.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: There's wooll in my scabbard, which is a spungious matter, and when I ha done (Musick Throne descends I may leave my drink behind me, and that's a hanging matter, which I am principally to avoid— Do you heare the Musick of the Spheres Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: From the roofe a Throne?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: This roome is mine, and cald the field of Tempe; Because I woonot stay while (The Wench peeps from under the Table .the Plaies are done when I have a humor to be merry, and drink healths in the clouds, I built this Elisium; and when bright Sack hath crown'd my brow, how soon I am made immortall, you may guesse.

lg.head: A Song in the Throne.
lg.l: As I singing now came down,
I do bring you Bacchus Crown:
From the plumpe Lord of the vine
Clusterd grapes to make you wine,
Your sweld Temples circling in,
Crown'd with this, and bath'd within;
Therefore your best wishes bring,
Place this Garland on your King.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Is not Bacchus the best good fellow God on 'em all? Let me see, Formall shall be King, and he sent to heaven presently.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Send me to heaven? why should I be sent thither before another man?

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: Ret, Ret, verily Ret, here's the Partridge under the Table.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They'l be good company, they shall both be immortall together, helpe Gentlemen. Boy you must be depos'd.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Alas what shall I doe?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You shall to heaven Lady?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: What before my time? and whether I will or no?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: It shall be with as much ease, as if it were in a Featherbed.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Let us sleepe together.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Ah pitty a poore Gentlewoman, if you have hearts of flesh, do not use me worse than heathen Prentices.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: So crowne 'm, and give to each a glasse of wine, for a scepter.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Gentlewoman, if we must mount, 'tis none of our seeking, we are but Angells in our owne defence, for my owne part, I desire to go thether in no better company.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Up with 'em, and preserve your scepter glasses, doe not spill your blood royall.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Alas, hold there for heavens sake, I must meet three Innes of court Gentlemen at the Stillyard to night, it may be out of my way 20. pound, consider your owne cases.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Peace gentle Queene of grapes.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Thou art a traitor too, oh!

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Doe not jog the chariot, let us take our preferment patiently, and drinke a health to the humble mortalls, that turne up their whites to us, this is pretty high drinking.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Drunkards, divells? oh that I were upon earth agen.—

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Is this the Gentlewomans wine, or water?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: He mounts insensibly.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They have a heavenly time on't; you know me sirra.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Noble Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: There's for your attendance.

sp.speaker: Jeer.
sp.p: What's to pay?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They shall pay you the reckoning in the other world, you know the back way thither; come my boyes to the departed, having paid all rites
We now returne.

sp.speaker: Jeerers.
sp.p: Like woefull Adamites.

div.head: Act. V. Scaena. I.
div.stage: Enter Simpleton, James, (little Table set out.)

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I Am resolved, since faire meanes cannot prevaile with Mistris Lucy, to steale her away, this is the key of the back-gate o'th' garden, to the fields, be ready when I give the signe to hurry her into the coach, and when I have her at my Countrey-House, Ile take in her maiden towne, upon my owne composition.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: You wo'not ravish her.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: There are twenty wayes to deale with a woman, and never ravish her; no, I have plaid the foole too much.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I am of your opinion.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But she shall find if I get possession.—

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: The Coachman is a lusty fellow too, and will help to clap her abroad; the curtaines being close she cannot be heard, and the horses will runne, as the devill were in the poope, for he drives like a Tamberlaine.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Holla ye pamperd Jades.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: One Traitour more were not amisse for al that.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Thou saist right, for though she be a little woman, her voyce may be too strong for us.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Let us alone, mind your owne part.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Be resolute James. — Exit Simp.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: The course I am in, hath brought some men to the Gallowes, and doe I take it for prevention?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: What desperate fellow's that?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I am weary of wine and noise, is there no other cure for melancholly? I doe not love the cramp in my necke.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: He lookes like a Gentleman that were in debt; my friend doe you come hither to finde a tree? th'art a proper fellow, dost want employment, for though your cloathes have a good glosse, they looke as they were ill lin'd, they want money.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I suffer that which made the old woman mend her pace fir.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Doe as Ile direct thee.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Whom doe you serve?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: I serve my selfe; my Master is a foole; did you never heare of Simpleton?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: That worshipfull puppy?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: He knowes him. I have seen you before, but 'tis no matter where; I like thy countenance; can'st keepe counsell? walke o'this hand o'me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay a little further Mistris Lucy, it seemes Mrs Voluble told him no great good fortune, she saw it in his starres, for you know she weares Astrology at her apron strings; but she told me in private who should be the man, your deere Endymion.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Who I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: The object is presented, and 'tis in vaine to oppose the Constellations, what must be must be, and there were no more Ladyes in the world, I am the man.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: To steale her away?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: My Master is resolv'd. They are here; close.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: She is betraid.—

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Now.—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Help; theeves.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Stop her mouth.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Then every man take his chance.

div.stage: (He strikes downe Simpleton. Lucy runs off.)

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Murther, murther.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Are you so cunning sir? you shall along with us. (They disarme New.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Worried by Hedghogs!

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Are you not kill'd outright sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I am not certaine, be sure you hold him fast; to the next Justice; I must get a Surgeon. You are my rivall, I know you well enough, if I miscarry, it shall cost me a hundred pound, but Ile ha thee hang'd for't. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: I understand you perfectly Mistris Voluble, and like your proposition; but a word more of the widdow that is at your 'house, shee is very rich you say?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Not in understanding.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: Tis the better.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Her's all your worship must promise her, to be knighted, for she hath a great mind to bee a Lady.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: I know where a blanck lies dormant for a Baronet, it will carry more noise and authority on the bench too.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You have done me some discourtesie here tofore, in beleeving the complaints of Intemperate tongues against me, but you see my charity I desire to live in your worships faire opinion as a neighbour.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: I will make you amends sweet Mistris Valuable, y'are a vertuous Gentlewoman on my conscience: but how shall this widdow be wrought?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
That's done already. The truth is she inquir'd
of me, (for we women use to open our secrets one to another) for some stayd Gentleman that was a Lawier, (because she has so great an estate, and many sutes to follow) on whom shee might bestow her selfe, for the security of her fortune, and I have already prepared her, and such a commendation of your person, and learned gravity, a Justice of Peace and Quorum, out of my private respects to you, without desire or expectation of any bribe or reward.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: I understand that very well.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I know you doe.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: How much I am bound to your vertue?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: The widdow has a great mind to see you, but I will contrive it for your honour, shee shall come hither, as to her learned Counsell.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: The invincible wit of a woman! how I honour it.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: There can bee no losse in't if you get a Chaplaine in readinesse, widowes are taken in the opportunitie.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: A Gentleman brought to be examined, that has wounded one Master Simpleton.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Simpleton? that's the widowes son.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Richard, send to the Curate of the Parish, say I would speake with him presently.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Alas who hurt you?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My rivall Master Newman, Is this the Justice?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
A former quarrell; if you die, I have saw
enough to make it murther, for your good Mothers sake.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Cannot you make it manslaughter, and let me live? for I desire but his death.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Hee shall make it what you please. This Gentleman is to bee Knighted, and loves your mother above all the world, things meet as close, as if they went to engender.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My Mother is worth six thousand pound, if you will promise to make her a Lady, and doe your best to hang the Gentleman, you shall be my Father in Law, when my Landlady sayes the word.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Sir Ile take my leave.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Sweet Mistris Voluble, leave your friend to me, I understand the matter perfectly, and it shall goe hard, but wee will have all the Law on our side. Call in the offender; please you sit; Richard be ready with your Ammunition, Pen, Inke and Paper.

div.stage: Enter Surgeon, Newman, Iames, Coachman, Constable and officers.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What is your name sir?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: My name is Seare.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: He is the Surgeon sir.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Ile teach you to follow your profession sirra, Ile make you an example to all Phlebotomers; how often have you beene indited for letting of blood sirra?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I understand you nor.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
But I understand you sirra; how durst you vi & armis, felloniously assault this noble Gentleman in contempt of peice, and the Kings Law,
his Crowne and dignity? answer me sirra to that. Ile seeze him.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: You Worship is mistaken, I never see the Gentleman before, I was sent for—

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: He is the Surgeon sir, that is come to take measure of my Masters wounds, it was that Gentleman that let him blood.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Why do they not change faces then? away you knave, and looke to the Gentleman; you stand idling here to stumble authority with a fellonious countenance.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Let us be for sworne both in a tale.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir, you are one that should doe Justice; where is my poore friend? bee not so much dejected, you did but rescue me sir from dishonour.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I was in a melancholly humour; 'tis come about as the wise woman concluded.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Wher's Simpleton? I may accuse him for a Rape.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Take heede what you say.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Or some such black intent; this Gentleman but interpos'd to save me from their fury, and with his sword punish'd a bold offender by letting out some blood that was corrupted.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: That's not materiall; will you confesse you wounded Master Simpleton? come to the matter.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I confesse it sir, but heare the reason.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
I will heare no reason, that were simple justice; take him aside, and you may follow your
businesse. Stay young Gentlewoman, I must examine you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Shall I withdraw, and shut the doore?

div.stage: Exeunt all but Iustice and Lucie.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What Justice sir, or Law is this?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: It is not Polton, Crompton, nor Fitzerhert, A Justice ought to have some discretion without booke, especially in these cases. I grant you are the root and cause of this misfortune.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I sir?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Be wise, and understand me; nd being indued with such gifts of nature, native beauty and favour, (come a little nearer) and you to abuse your selfe—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Or suffer your selfe to be abused (come a little nearer) is not to be thankefull for those excellent benefits.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Will you translate an Insolence in others upon my guilt?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: You accuse an honest Gentleman for an intent of rape; alas poore soule, it was pure affection in him, hee would have ravished you no doubt, with your owne consent, the fault was your Ingratitude, (a little nearer) Seneca doth write much of Ingratitude, that I may come (a little nearer) or else Nero had not let him blood, (yet nearer) this Nero was a most wicked Tyrant, for all he could play upon a fidle, make ballads, and sing them himselfe, and therefore take heede of cruelty, and be gentle, he kisseth her .for, sweet-heart Nero died a violent death.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: My Mother.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Lucy you made haste.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Your pardon Madam.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: I understand she is a Lady.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: In the defence of my owne vertue, and the noble Gentleman that suffers for his charity to me—

sp.speaker: Beauf.
sp.p: I came to assist you. It were an injurie to doubt your justice. My name is Beaufield. If my credit may be interpos'd security for Newman my daughters knowledge in the cause will Enter Clarke .give a most cleare satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Richard, call in the delinquent, this Lady has spoken very much to the matter, as I understand it. Has the Surgeon done yet?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: They are comming downe.

div.stage: Enter Surgeon, Newman, Simpleton, Iames, Constable, Officers.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Now sir, how many of his wounds are mortall?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: There is not one considerable, the Gentleman is in no danger.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But have not you authority to hang him? Ile take my oath, he had an intent to kill me. My Lady and Mistris Lucie? Iames, Ile stay no longer, since I am not mortally wounded, sneake after me.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: My hanging fit is over, and the witchcraft, I am now my selfe again, if you can pardon Enter Manley .me Madam this too great an honour to your worthlesse servant.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: How now? what saucie fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Shee's here too. I am bold Cozen to visit you, they say, ther's a Gentleman brought before you, for breach o'th' peace, I come to baile him.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: We take no forrainers; what outlandish thing are you, pray?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You know me sir, my name is Manley, you calld me cozen yesterday.

sp.speaker: Lust.
sp.p: I never saw you before. I know that name, and a Gentleman that ownes it, a kinsman of mine too, but he is no such Brandemart. Richard, doe you know this Mahound? he calls himselfe my cozen Manly.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Why in this habit?

sp.speaker: Iust
sp.p: Transmigration?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Is it not some spie sir?

sp.speaker: Iust
sp.p: Constable take him to your charge. Ile teach you sirra, to usurpe a Gentlemans name; tis fellony ipso facto, write his mittimus.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: By what statute? Trigesimo Secundo of King Phillip? I doe not Madam desire your certificate.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Y'are a stranger sir to me, yet I dare bee engag'd for his forth comming, hee has an honest face.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Come hither Richard, there's halfe a peece, rub thy eyes woo't, are they open yet?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
I see you plainely now sir, y'are my Masters
cozen, 'tis Master Manley.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: 'Tis your best course to owne me too; is it so long since you tooke bribes, since you divided and manumisd a crooked chambermaid that robd her Mistris of old Gold? there was a Lancepresado stript a hedge, when you were out of Linnen; Peuter has been left at the back-doore, when you did study Alchymie; I leave the tricke you shew'd the Sailors wife in your Closet, when you promis'd a reprieve to her goodman from Wapping; I know not that you have run your wither'd motley face into a premunire; doe not know me, why d'ee not charge the constable?

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: What is a Justice without eyes, I meane spectacles? 'tis he indeed, I understand, and see him perfectly; welcome, a Chaire for my Cosen?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So then. Madam a word with you, I'le make you know me too, ere I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: There is a matted Chamber & a Couch— More businesse?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vere is de matre Justice? begar dey have put de sheare upon me, me expect de rish vidow, and have marry the chambermaid, she confesse dat, Maitre Justice, pray take her to your selfe, me desire your varrant, for Metresse Voluble, dat she bring the vidow Simplaton to marry me sans ceremoine, dat is your commission, or begar me complaine of you to de King.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: Did you expect the rich widow Simpleton? ha, ha! I know this trifle, my Clarke knowes her better

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Bergar Matre Justice, and Matre Clarke make your division, dat is all you see.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Sir I have onely cause to complaine, he told me he was a French Lord, Mistris Voluble shall make affidavit, and courted me to be his Lady, and now we are married, he proves but a cinquepace. I look'd for thousands per annum, and he is but one, two, three, foure, and five.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: How, did he pretend himselfe to be a Lord? 'tis Scandalum Magnatum in the highest degree: and by a statute quinquagesimo of the Queene, if she prosecute, he is to be whip'd, and lose his eares three severall market dayes.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: How will you divide his Eares into three equall portions?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me give a de whip, and me lose a mine 'ares!

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: You heare the law, if I complaine.

sp.speaker: I. Ieer.
sp.p: Sir— Mistris Voluble—

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Is the widow come?

sp.speaker: I Ieer.
sp.p: The Gentlewoman is come, and desires to speake with your worship in private.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: The Curat's in the Hall sir.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: So, so, I must intreate your patience for a few minutes; how I am blest! Exit.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Tell a me de trot, have you no Argent, no portion?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: But I have a trade.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I dare be sworne thou hast.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Aw dat is someting, here is my hand, you no tell a de tale, a me, and me keepe your Enter Sir William, and Mother.
secret by my trot.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I tooke boldnesse Madam upon sight of your Ladiships new Coach at the doore, to entrude and present a poore forsaken servant; give you joy of your old fashion'd young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Your companion wants no antiquity, if she have no Visard on.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I hope you are not married Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: The matters done, and tis more honourable to make a Lady than to marry one. Does any body know this Gentlewoman, she was a widow till this morning, and a rich one I thanke my staires, and wants the subtile art, some Ladyes have to make themselves ridiculous, by doting upon anticks.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: What name has your most reverend Lady?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: She was called the wealthy widow of old Simpleton, before I married her.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What Is't makes you so merry Mounsieur?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar some body make arrant asse of de Knight, hold a me, or me shall cracke a my rib wi'de laugh, dat is no Simplaton, but an autre Chambermaid, de servant to my vife, begar he be sheated too.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I must confesse she waited upon me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Ma foy dat is certaine, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I desie her, that was but a plot.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Begar it was very fine a plot, me have
patience, dat dere be more foole in de comedy.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Mistris Voluble can justifie what I am, that I am, or would I might nere be, a Lady, and I be'nt, that I be'nt.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I will have Justice.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You may have him sir.

sp.speaker: Iustice
sp.p: The reason of this noyse my right worshipfull?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Give me a warrant presently.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Against whom?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Voluble, I'le have her whip'd.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Wrong not the vertuous Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Vertuous? vexation.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why doe you take on so, o' my conscience she is honest enough; does this woman looke like a whore?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I thanke you Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: She has gravity enough to be a bawde, and then the worst is past.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Is not the widow weight, not perfect sterling?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: This is not the widow.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What widow?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: The rich widow Simpleton.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: I doe believe it, did she promise you marriage?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: The devills proctor Mistris Voluble made me believe so.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
Doe not wrong I say agen that vertuous Gentlewoman Mistris Voluble, I know her, and know her vertuous, but the rich widow Simpleton, you talke of (thankes be to providence) is
newly married, the Priest hath scarce wip'd his oraculous lips, since they pronounc'd us, Man Enter Voluble, and two Ieerers (at one doore) Simpleton, at the other. )and Wife, in my stone Parlour, in good faith la, she's here, her owne tongue will confirme it Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Why does she veile her face.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: It is her modesty, to hide her blushes, that I should so soone prevaile upon her: and thus the morning breakes out of the cloudes.

sp.speaker: Simpl.
sp.p: By your leave Landlady, wher's my mother.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Mistris Voluble?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Here's my son, he shall be a witnesse I am his mother, I am married to this Knight, and they would perswade me out of my selfe.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: 'Tis come about agen, Is this your mother?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I have asked her blessing in my dayes.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: There is no remedy, 'twas your owne Curate did it.

sp.speaker: Ieer
sp.p: Give you joy Mr. Justice.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Conspiracy, is there no law for this?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Yes, yes, the canon law, and you must keepe her.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Let me obtaine Madam your faire construction, Sir William you are sped to your desires, and you are fitted Mounsieur Galliard, but Nice, the Jewells must returne to their right owner.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Excuse a moy.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: It must be so, I keepe my wedding ring for thee sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
I aske you pardon sir, and Mistris Lucy,
I had a plot upon your loves, to endeare young Simpleton, in hope your credulous nature, to avoid melancholy, might have beene engag'd to some licentious rudenesse, and so made your self unworthy of her affection, but here I must confesse I have no skill in starres nor fortune telling, and am but one among the rest that have deceiv'd your easy faith, forgive me, as I wish you may thrive in your affections.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I am confirm'd.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Nay then let marriages goe round, with this take both possession of my heart and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You but inlarge my power to doe you service.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Your love, and joyes be constant. Mr. Iustice you must embrace Mistris Voluble.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Well, I will love thee for thy wit; but no more wandring.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You wholly sir shall steere me, and to invite more welcome from you sir, I have not liv'd upon the common charity, I have a state is not to be despis'd.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Saist thou so, wee'l put our stocks together and live merrily.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Will they not take his word? alas poore Formall, there, there's their ransome, bid the whore be honest, I'le plead his reconcilement to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Ieere Ma.
sp.p: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But d'ee heare, must I ha' no wench, at the end of the play? that have taken all this paines? what will you doe with me?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
Well remembred, this Lady did accuse
him; though I miss'd of the Mother, I will make sure of the son, make his warrant for Newgate presently.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.p: I know how very well Sir.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: You call'd it love before, I freely pardon him.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Let this Day be consecrate to peace, and Hymen.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: And the Night to Venus; let it be so, and thanke this Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I thanke you all, and will never trust a witch for your sake, I'le goe seeke out my wits.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.l: Let no man part, so many hearts here tid'd,
Stay till we drinke a health to every Bride.
Florish—
